task-wr.title: Installing Patches
task-wr.shortdesc: US62817 changed wrs-patch -> sw-patchAfter adding a patch to the patch storage area, you must move it to the software updates repository, which manages patch distribution for the cluster. From there, you can install patches to the hosts that require them.

prereq.p: Before you can install a patch, you must make it available by adding it to the patch storage area. For more information, see .

context.p: Some of the available patches may be required on controller hosts only, while others may be required on compute or storage hosts. When you apply an available patch, it is added to the software updates repository, ready for installation on any host type that requires it. You can then install all applicable patches to each host in turn.
To keep track of patch installation, you can use the sw-patch query command.

codeblock.systemoutput: ﻿ Patch ID Patch State ========================= =========== TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0001 Available TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0002 Available TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0003 Available

context.p: This shows the Patch State for each of the patches in the patch storage area:

dd.p: A patch in the Available state has been added to the patch storage area, but has not yet been added to the software updates repository or installed on the hosts.

A patch in the Partial-Apply state has been added to the software updates repository using the sw-patch apply command, but has not been installed on all hosts that require it. It may have been installed on some but not others, or it may not have been installed on any hosts.

A patch in the Applied state has been installed on all hosts that require it, using either the system host-patch-reboot command (for use with a locked host) or the sw-patch host-install command (for use with an unlocked host, for example during controller configuration).

context.p: You can use the sw-patch query-hosts command to see which hosts are fully patched (Patch Current). This also shows which hosts require reboot, either because they are not fully patched, or because they are fully patched but need restarting to make the patches take effect.

codeblock.systemoutput: ﻿ Hostname IP Address Patch Current Reboot Required ============ ============== ============= =============== compute-0 192.168.204.15 Yes No controller-0 192.168.204.3 No Yes controller-1 192.168.204.4 No Yes

context.p: The following example illustrates the process of installing a single patch on the cluster. It assumes that the patch is in the Available state already, as described in , and that only the controller nodes must be patched.

step.cmd: Verify that the patches are available using the command sw-patch query.

codeblock.systemoutput: ﻿ Patch ID Patch State ========================= =========== TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0001 Available TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0002 Available TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0003 Available
TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0001 is now in the repo

stepresult.p: The patch is now in the Partial-Apply state, ready for installation from the software updates repository on the impacted hosts.

step.cmd: Apply all available patches in a single operation.

codeblock.systemoutput: TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0001 is now in the repo
TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0002 is now in the repo
TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0003 is now in the repo

info.p: In this example there are three patches ready now for installation from the software updates repository.

step.cmd: Query the patching status of all hosts in the cluster.

info.p: You can query the patching status of all hosts at any time as illustrated below. Note that the reported status is the accumulated result of all applied and removed patches in the software updates repository, and not just the status due to a particular patch.

codeblock.systemoutput: ﻿ Hostname IP Address Patch Current Reboot Required ============ ============== ============= =============== compute-0 192.168.204.15 Yes No controller-0 192.168.204.3 No Yes controller-1 192.168.204.4 No Yes

stepresult.p: For each host in the cluster, the following patch status fields are displayed:

dd.p: Indicates whether there are patches pending for installation or removal on the host or not. If Yes, then all relevant patches in the software updates repository have been installed on, or removed from, the host already. If No, then there is at least one patch in either the Partial-Apply or Partial-Remove states that has not been applied to the host.
Indicates whether the host has to be rebooted or not as a result of one or more patches that have been either applied or removed, or because it is not patch current.

stepresult.p: In this example, compute-0 is up to date, no patches need to be installed and no reboot is required. By contrast, the controllers are not patch current, and therefore a reboot is required to install the patch.

step.cmd: Install all pending patches on controller-0.

info.p: Before patching a controller node, you must transfer any active services running on the host to the other controller. Only then it is safe to lock the host.
The patching sequence locks the host, installs the patches, and forces a host reboot.

step.cmd: Manually install all pending patches on controller-0.

info.p: You may want to have finer control of the patching steps executed by the system host-patch-reboot command to determine when to install the patches and unlock the host.
Before patching a controller node, you must transfer any active services running on the host to the other controller. Only then it is safe to lock the host.
You must lock the target host, controller, compute, or storage, before installing patches.

codeblock.systemoutput: Patch installation was successful on controller-0

codeblock.systemoutput: ﻿ Hostname IP Address Patch Current Reboot Required ============ ============== ============= =============== compute-0 192.168.204.15 Yes No controller-0 192.168.204.3 Yes Yes controller-1 192.168.204.4 No Yes

stepresult.p: For illustration purposes in this section, the command sw-patch host-install is presented as the tool to install patches. But in fact, this command also removes patches as well, as described in . The command is better described then as the tool to install and remove all patches in the Partial-Apply and Partial-Remove states on a host.
Unlocking the host forces a reset of the host followed by a reboot. This ensures that the host is restarted in a known state.
All patches are now installed on controller-0.

step.cmd: Confirm that all patches are installed and the HP Helion OpenStack Carrier Grade cluster is up-to-date.

info.p: Use the sw-patch query command to verify that all patches are Applied.

codeblock.systemoutput: ﻿ Patch ID Patch State ========================= =========== TITANIUM_14.10_PATCH_0001 Applied

info.p: If the Patch State for any patch is still shown as Available or Partial-Apply, use the sw-patch query-hosts command to identify which hosts are not Patch Current, and then apply patches to them as described in the preceding steps.
